Column Comment.0: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for this row.
Column Comment.1: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.2: CORE ID: Unique identifier for a well core
Column Comment.3: ANALYSIS OBSERVATION NUMBER: Number for each unique analysisobservation.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: CORE SOLVENT: The solvent used for removing residual fluids from the core. Forexample, a common fluid used for distillation-extraction is toluene.
Column Comment.6: CUTTING FLUID: The type of fluid used to cut the core into samples. For example:water, brine.
Column Comment.7: DENSITY ANALYSIS: Describes the method used for density measurements (e.g.,Boyle"s Law) .
Column Comment.8: DRYING METHOD: Narrative text on the method used to dry the core plug after thecleaning process, such as high temperature oven.
Column Comment.9: DRY TEMPERATURE: Temperature maintained during the drying process.
Column Comment.10: DRYING TEMPERATURE OUOM: Drying temperature original unit of measure.
Column Comment.11: CORE DRYING TIME ELAPSED: Time required to dry the core after the extractionprocess has been completed.
Column Comment.12: DRYING TIME ELAPSED OUOM: Core dry time original unit of measure.
Column Comment.13: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.14: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.15: EXTRACT METHOD: Descriptive comments associated with the method used toextract any residual fluids present in the core plug (e.g., vacuum distillation)
Column Comment.16: EXTRACT TIME ELAPSED: Time required to extract any residual fluids present inthe core.
Column Comment.17: EXTRACTION TIME ELAPSED OUOM: Core extraction time original unit ofmeasure.
Column Comment.18: FLUID SATURATION ANALYSIS: Comments on the method used for fluid saturation(e.g., solvent extraction, vacuum distillation, retort, etc.).
Column Comment.19: PERMEABILITY ANALYSIS: Any comment about the method used to measurepermeability (e.g., Darcy"s Law, empirical technique, etc.).
Column Comment.20: POROSITY ANALYSIS: Describes the method used to measure porosity (e.g.,Boyle"s Law, Helium, Retort fluids, etc.).
Column Comment.21: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.22: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
